name: Merge k Sorted Lists

similar_questions.title: Smallest Subarrays With Maximum Bitwise OR

title: Merge k Sorted Lists
content:
You are given an array of k linked-lists lists, each linked-list is sorted in ascending order.

Merge all the linked-lists into one sorted linked-list and return it.

 

Example 1:

Input: lists = [[1,4,5],[1,3,4],[2,6]]
Output: [1,1,2,3,4,4,5,6]
Explanation: The linked-lists are:
[
  1->4->5,
  1->3->4,
  2->6
]
merging them into one sorted linked list:
1->1->2->3->4->4->5->6

Example 2:

Input: lists = []
Output: []

Example 3:

Input: lists = [[]]
Output: []

 

Constraints:

  • k == lists.length
  • 0 <= k <= 104
  • 0 <= lists[i].length <= 500
  • -104 <= lists[i][j] <= 104
  • lists[i] is sorted in ascending order.
  • The sum of lists[i].length will not exceed 104.

discussion_posts.name: franciscocw0101
discussion_posts.content: The one hard problem I feel confident solving but then gets ruined by a top comment saying it shouldn\'t be a hard problem :(

discussion_posts.name: adambene
discussion_posts.content: This problem should not be marked as hard.\nMedium is more proper based on the other problems on leetcode.

discussion_posts.name: David_E_something
discussion_posts.content: If you somehow use a priority queue (heap), this problem becomes very easy.

discussion_posts.name: viocost
discussion_posts.content:
The problem is interesting, but why there are test cases such as [[], []] 
and not a word about possible inputs expected output?

Is it also a telepathy exercise?

discussion_posts.name: Salmondita007
discussion_posts.content: They should add Deloitte to the list for companies because I got this exact problem in a coding interview with Deloitte

discussion_posts.name: Kouei
discussion_posts.content:
The fastest C++ code can achieve a time about 370ms ~ 380ms

while Python code can achieve 100ms, and even amazing, JAVA can do it in just 4ms !

This result is quite counterintuitive.

discussion_posts.name: alistar
discussion_posts.content: With empty list it seems to expect an empty list as an output, however, it doest not accept it with type-error.\nLitterally copied and pasted one of the official solutions, it doesn\'t go through with the same issue!

discussion_posts.name: dkrants
discussion_posts.content: This problem indeed gets solved easily by throwing all node values into one array and then sorting it. This makes the "sorted in ascending order" part of the problem statement irrelevant.\n\nIMO the problem should explicitly state that you are not allowed to mutate list nodes.  Then it would justify its "hard" rating.

discussion_posts.name: JaviOverflow
discussion_posts.content: When I submit my solution, it fails on the input `[[]]`, how is that input even posible? `ListNode` requires `val` as argument in its constructor. Returning `None` doesn\'t make the test pass. I\'m not sure how to tackle that.
